page.title: 15Burton Pits
page.content: Three miles north west of Lincoln between the A57 road and Burton Village there is a nature reserve known as Burton Pits.It is run by the Lincolnshire and South Humberside Trust for Nature Conservation.The reserve covers 69 acres. Until 1963 gravel was being excavated from the pits.It is made up of five small pits. There are about 180 different species of birds. Some of the rarer birds to be seen are the red necked grebe and black tern. Kingfishers can be seen throughout the year. As well as birds there are rare wild flowers, moths, butterflies, fungi, bats and insects. The woodland is well establish with many types of trees including birch, elm, sycamore, beech and oak. There is a hide to watch water birds on the largest pit. Fishing is allowed with a special permit.
